title: Logfmt index
description:
Dedicated logfmt indexer that assumes the entire line is logfmt format.

Unlike the generic KV index (which is conservative to avoid false positives on arbitrary text), this indexer can use a proper logfmt parser that handles:
- Hyphenated keys (pod-name=api-server, container-id=abc123)
- Bare/boolean keys (active without = means true)
- Escape sequences in quoted values (msg="has \"quotes\"")
- Colons and other special characters in keys (service:name=api)

Consider using go-logfmt/logfmt as the parser. The indexer should produce the same index format as the KV index (key=value pairs) so existing query infrastructure works unchanged.

title: Retention policies (TTL, size-based, background cleanup)
description:
Implement a retention policy system for stores. A policy defines when chunks should be deleted — by age (TTL) or by total store size (keep last N bytes). A background goroutine periodically evaluates policies and removes expired/excess chunks.

Consolidates:
- 3u5j — Background cleanup goroutine
- 441g — Size-based retention (keep last N bytes)
- 4brs — TTL-based chunk deletion

title: Cron-based chunk rotation
description: Add a cron schedule option to rotation policies. Instead of rotating based on size/age/record count thresholds evaluated at append time, a cron-based policy rotates chunks on a fixed schedule (e.g. every hour, daily at midnight). This requires a background timer rather than the current per-record check in the append path.

title: Unified logging for all chunk rotation events
description: Cron-based rotation logs seal events to stdout, but threshold-based rotation (size, age, record count) happens silently inside ChunkManager.Append() without logging. All rotation events should be logged consistently regardless of trigger.

title: Migrate retention sweeps to shared scheduler
description: Retention currently runs as a per-store goroutine with time.Ticker at a hardcoded 1-minute interval. This should be migrated to the shared Scheduler so retention jobs are visible alongside cron rotation jobs, and the interval becomes configurable via cron expressions rather than hardcoded.

title: Migrate index builds and other ad-hoc tasks to shared scheduler
description:
Index builds are currently managed as unbounded goroutines tracked by indexWg/indexCtx in the orchestrator. These should be migrated to the shared Scheduler using gocron's OneTimeJob support, which would make them visible in ScheduledJobs(), provide built-in concurrency limiting via WithLimitConcurrentJobs, and consolidate shutdown handling.

Beyond index builds, audit the orchestrator for any other ad-hoc goroutine-managed work that could benefit from moving to the scheduler. Candidates might include ingester lifecycle management or any future background tasks.

The Scheduler wrapper will need a new RunOnce method backed by OneTimeJob(OneTimeJobStartImmediately()).

title: Relative time ranges (last=5m) instead of absolute start/end
notes: The sidebar time range presets (5m, 15m, etc.) bake absolute start=/end= timestamps into the query at click time. Re-running the search returns stale results because the time window is frozen. Presets should emit last=5m instead, resolved server-side at query time.

title: Configurable max concurrent scheduler jobs

title: Structural JSON index (GIN-style path/containment queries)
notes:
The current JSON extractor flattens shallow JSON into key=value pairs with dot-separated paths. This works for flat/simple JSON logs but falls short for deeply nested structures, arrays of objects, and keys that contain dots.

A proper structural JSON index would support:
- Arrays of objects: spans[*].attributes.db.statement
- Deep nesting beyond 4 levels
- Distinguishing dotted keys (service.name as single key) from nested paths
- Containment queries (does this record's JSON contain this sub-structure)
- Path existence queries

Conceptually similar to PostgreSQL's GIN index for JSONB. Would likely need a new index format and query syntax extensions.

title: RELP ingester (reliable syslog transport)
notes: RELP (Reliable Event Logging Protocol) ingester for receiving logs from rsyslog and other RELP-capable senders. RELP provides reliable delivery over TCP with transaction-based acknowledgements, preventing message loss during network issues or receiver restarts. Commonly used in enterprise syslog infrastructure as a more reliable alternative to plain TCP/UDP syslog.

title: File tail ingester (local log file watching)
notes:
Native file tailing ingester for watching local log files without requiring external forwarders like rsyslog or Promtail. Should support:
- Glob patterns for file discovery (e.g., /var/log/*.log)
- Position bookmarking across restarts
- Log rotation detection (inode tracking, truncation detection)
- Re-evaluation of glob patterns for new/removed files
- Configurable poll interval

title: Backpressure signaling
description: Signal backpressure from chunk managers to ingesters when ingestion is too fast.
notes:
Go's blocking semantics provide basic backpressure for free — if chunk Append blocks, the ingester goroutine stops reading from the network, TCP buffers fill, and the sender slows down.

This issue covers explicit backpressure beyond the implicit kind:
- Return HTTP 429 / RELP NACK instead of just being slow
- Drop low-priority messages under load instead of blocking everything
- Observable metrics on queue depth and backpressure events
- Configurable buffer limits before implicit backpressure kicks in

title: Distributed Architecture & Horizontal Scaling
notes: Support for running multiple GastroLog instances in a distributed topology. Covers federation (querying across instances), headless agents for remote log collection, cluster coordination, and data replication.

title: Headless agent mode
notes: Lightweight GastroLog instance that tails local files and forwards to a central instance. No UI, minimal footprint, configured via file or flags. Pairs with the file tail ingester (2pr9) on the agent side and any protocol ingester on the central side.

title: Federated search
notes: Query multiple GastroLog instances from a single UI. A central instance fans out queries to remotes and merges results in timestamp order. Needs a query forwarding API and result stream merging.

title: Cluster discovery and membership
notes: Instances discover each other and track health. Options: static config, DNS-based, or gossip protocol. Foundation for federated search and shard routing.

title: Data replication
notes: Replicate sealed chunks between instances for redundancy. At least leader-follower replication of sealed chunks. Stretch goal: multi-writer with conflict resolution.

title: Shard-based ingestion routing
notes: Route incoming logs to specific instances based on store, source, or consistent hashing. Spreads write load across nodes. Requires cluster membership awareness.

title: Remote chunk transfer
notes: API for transferring sealed chunks between instances. Enables rebalancing, migration, cold storage offloading, and data replication. Chunks are immutable once sealed, making transfer straightforward.

title: User registration and login
description: Basic user accounts with email/password registration, login, and session management.
notes:
Keep it simple: username + bcrypt password, SQLite storage, session tokens.

Registration: username + password → bcrypt hash → store in SQLite.
Login: verify hash → create session (random token + expiry) → return token.
Auth: Authorization header with bearer token → session lookup → get user.

No OAuth, no JWT, no email verification. Those can be layered on later.

Bootstrap: If no users exist, the UI shows a first-time setup screen to create the initial admin account. Once created, the setup screen disappears and normal login takes over. Must work without CLI access (Docker containers).

title: Server-side KV config store
notes:
Simple key-value store in SQLite for server configuration that doesn't belong in the static config file. Key is text, value is JSON-serialized text. Avoids schema migrations for every new parameter.

Examples of what goes here:
- JWT signing secret (generated on first boot)
- Feature flags
- Runtime-adjustable settings (e.g., max concurrent scheduler jobs)

Queryable from the backend without restart. Distinct from user preferences (2m25), which are per-user — this is system-wide.

title: API authentication (JWT/session tokens)
description:
Authenticate API requests via JWT. Short-lived access tokens verified by signature (no server-side session lookup). Refresh tokens for renewal. Protect endpoints that require a logged-in user. Connect RPC middleware to extract and validate the token on each request.

Token durations (access + refresh) should be adjustable via the KV config store (1ulp). JWT signing secret is persisted in the KV store so tokens survive backend restarts.

Token duration is adjustable via the server config in the KV settings store. JWT signing secret is auto-generated during bootstrap and persisted in the KV store so tokens survive backend restarts.

No refresh tokens — simplified to a single long-lived token per the decision in 54xw.

title: Frontend login and registration UI
description:
The backend now enforces auth on all non-public endpoints (2bod). The frontend needs:

1. Auth state management: React context for token storage (localStorage), auth status
2. Transport interceptor: attach Authorization Bearer header to all Connect RPC requests
3. Auth client: instantiate AuthService client in client.ts
4. Registration screen: shown when GetAuthStatus returns needs_setup=true (no users exist)
5. Login screen: shown when user has no valid token but users exist
6. Auth hooks: useLogin, useRegister, useAuthStatus, useLogout
7. Route guard: redirect to login/register when unauthenticated

The frontend should call GetAuthStatus on startup to determine whether to show registration or login. After successful login/register, store the token and attach it to all subsequent requests.

title: Click histogram bar segment to filter by level
description: Clicking a colored segment in the histogram should add a level filter to the current query. For example, clicking a red (error) segment appends `level=error` to the search, clicking yellow appends `level=warn`, etc. Clicking the copper (default/no level) segment appends `not level=*` to filter for records with no level attribute. This lets users quickly drill down from the visual overview into specific severity levels.

title: Add support for multiple color themes
description:
The frontend already uses CSS custom properties for all colors (~50 tokens), making it straightforward to support multiple themes beyond the current Observatory palette.

Each theme provides its own dark and light variant. The c() helper continues to pick between dark/light — themes just redefine what those colors are by swapping CSS variable values.

Implementation:
- Define theme palettes as CSS variable sets in main.css (e.g., .theme-observatory { ... }, .theme-nord { ... })
- Apply theme class to root element
- Extend Theme type and preferences to store both mode (dark/light/system) and palette
- Add theme picker UI (either in settings or alongside the existing mode toggle)
- Each palette defines both dark and light variants of all ~50 color tokens
